												KNIFE to meet you! - AnnoymousTHE GOODShank controls nicely on the gamepad (Which is what the devs want you to play this on) and feel better than the PC controls, although Shank is a spam fest either way. Button-mashing is inevitable and gameplay is repetative as the same enemies will attack you in the same ways. I never said that it wasn't fun though, as Shank pulls it off with such style that I really cannot find the gameplay boring. Sure the enemies will take a long time to kill and you will take some damage in the process but it's fair and will drop you health and extra weapons for your troubles.THE GREATGraphically I cannot find fault with Shank's aesthetic. The character animations are smooth, the character models are functional, the backgrounds (Silhouettes) do thier job and the scenery looks pleasing at the very least. Shank seems to break up the fighting from time to time by adding in puzzle sections which flows nicely and gives players hands a rest from the constant button-mashing. Mechanics of Shank are fairly simple with not too much getting in the way of redecorating the walls with enemies intestines, and on the topic of intestines it feels like the devolpers wanted this to be more violent in parts. I expected some gruesome deaths from enemies once I got a high enough combo which makes you feel that this game is censored. We'll get to that later.THE UGLYIt's later. The story is absolutely terrible and it seems that the main character, appropriately named Shank is just out to kill the Big Bad because he doesn't lke him. I played the Steam version through to the second boss fight and then downloaded the Humble Bundle 4 version (Which I got a while ago) and noticed that the cutscenes had been changed to the point where the story makes no sense. I cannot understand why Steam would censor an M rated game, but I'm not complaining. The only other real issue is the fact that this game was made for the gamepad. It says so on the intro screen and shows it by having the default controls worse than my home country's rating system. These are two seemingly petty gripes but they really ruin the experince.THE VERDICTDo you see how I've recommended this game? I've recommended it on two conditions. These follow:1- You own a gamepad as the default and customizable controls are terrible2- You don't care about the story/you watch the cutscenes through YouTube to grasp the story/you'll played this game on console and know the storyThese are the only conditions I would recommend Shank and that's a real shame because I like Shank, I possibly even love Shank, but if I'm being honest then that's my recommendation to you.SIMILAR GAMES-Rocketbirds: Hardboiled Chicken for it's crazy, fun, spam fest attitude-Mark Of The Ninja for the unique and eye-catching styleFor more reviews check out http://steamcommunity.com/groups/truereview

												A nicely done sidescroller brawler with revenge story.Common problems, complaints with the game and their fixes:  the updated game removed some cutscenes because they retroactively changed their minds about what's beneficial to the game and what looks decent, removing the more bloody/aggressive parts for whatever reason (blood flows with every landed hit anyways...) ---> you can rightclick on the game in library, go to properties, then betas, and activate [shank classic]. You'll get achivements, everything works, and you'll get back the original cutscenes.  Also, if you play a game on a windows account that has non-english characters in it's name, the game won't be able to save. The fix is simple, create a new win login on the pc, it takes only 2-3 minutes.And then about the game: the game goes roughly one (or two) normal levels, then a bossfight, unlocking new weapons as the game goes on. I played with a controller and the controls are absolutely on the point, easy, well-flowing experience. The story is alright, the main charm of the game is the fighting, managing a group of enemies with different attack styles and patterns and the game does a good job at it.   Normal difficulty's campaign is roughly 3 hours long, the game has a local coop story campaign (different one), with the use of joytokey or similar programs you can bind P1 and P2's controls to the same buttons, so it's even playeable alone :)  The game is a nice brawler-like game, with the bosses being focused on dodging and counterattacking a lot - I think normal mode offers a pleasant challenge and nice story for everyone, as checkpoints are forgiving, always spawning again with 3 granades.extra about the hard difficulty: It's a slightly negative aspect how much of an overkill hard difficulty is - having no checkpoints on whole levels while doing considerably less damage, while punishing super-hard for buttonsmashing / not dodging in time. They ocassionally stunlock you, and dropped health is extremely inconsistant (Big Guys drop hp, sometimes after fighting two I got 0, 1 or two health potions) and one of the later levels features a constant rocket barrage that was a pain in the butt even on normal...  so if you'd like to try hard difficulty, it's *really* hard compared to the normal, a real challenge, maybe a little more than it would be necessary.

												I would love to love this game. It has a fantastic presentation with a Mexican desert flavor, great animation, big boss fights, a plethora of different looking enemies and it is a 2D beat em up published EA (but people think its indie). Its just not fun. In an era full of Metroidvanias beat em ups such as Guacamelee, you will find Shank is more of a basic left to right sidescroller with very few ups and downs. There are no secret areas or even breakable walls with meat in them. If the original Castlevania had secrets, why not Shank?The game has great controls, a quick melee button, strong melee button, a gun attack, a pounce button, grapple button, grenade button, block button and even a jump. It has everything that you'd ever want in a 2D beat em up. With all of that being said, it feels so monotonous. Your attacks feel very weak and each enemy takes an exorbitant amount of hits. The enemies are pretty smart, they'll block and roll through you to sandwich you between enemies. If they have enough distance, they'll pull a gun out and shoot. While there are a lot of different looking enemies, they all pretty much fall into a few categories. Standard foot soldiers, big brawlers, weapon users and dogs. The game is very forgiving on normal mode. There are no lives, you just respawn pretty close to where you died. It is a welcome decision to do so. Of course, there is a hard mode too.The problem with the game is that it gets dull really quick especially when you have the same attacks from start to finish. You gain no new abilities to keep things fresh. There are a few extra guns and strong melee weapons that you can use, but nothing feels like an upgrade, just a sidegrade. The bosses boil down to finding a weakness to exploit, pouncing on them and stabbing them.There are light traversals to break up combat for a mere two seconds, such as climbing a brief fall, briefly hanging from a pipe or jumping platform to platform, but it just needed more of a break from the monotony of combat. It is so odd that there can be so much diversity in combat, and yet you can still just button mash your way to victory. Also what does it say about Shank's combat when the next game the creators made after Shank 2 was a stealth game? Another issue with the game is the blah music.There is co-op to improve the experience, but having a friend around can improve any experience. I'm from an era of Nintendo and Super Nintendo beat em ups that have less combat options, but more enemy diversity. I just couldn't get into Shank.Finally, there will be plenty of sales if not game bundles with Shank 1 and 2. Just wait for the combo pack sales with $5 for both.

												Shank is one of those games that I've had in my library for months and never got around to playing until now. And now that I have played it, I'm sure glad I did. I haven't beaten the game yet, but I can tell it's going to be a real winner.The first thing I noticed about the game is the incredible art style. It's cartoonish, and some people might think that would detract from a gritty, blood-soaked beat-em-up, but it fits perfectly with this game. Shank's art style reminds me of Skullgirls or Guacamelee, just cartoony enough to make everything seem surreal, without feeling like a Mario game. The colorful landscapes and enemies that you encounter really make this game stand out.The soundtrack is spectacular, and really adds to the depth of the game. Shank really feels great, and a big part of that is the exceptional music. The sound effects are great as well, really reminding me of old beat-em-ups like X-Men or TMNT with all the grunts and yelling and slashing. Gameplay is a little complicated, because Shank is able to use several weapons and several different kinds of attacks. I've been playing this game with an XBox controller, and it feels very intuitive. The only thing I don't like is that at certain points of the game, it will prompt you to hit a particular button, but the prompt just shows a little cartoon of what the button does so it can be hard to remember which button to press. For example, to pick up items, you have to push down and lunge at the same time, and instead of showing "RT" for lunge, it's just a silhouette of Shank lunging. This is only mildly annoying though, because you will quickly learn what each button does and how to pick up items so it won't matter what the prompt looks like. So far, the story is very well written and I'm enjoying it quite a bit. One complaint that I have is that there is no option for subtitles, so make sure your volume is turned up. I usually like to listen to music in iTunes while I play games, so this was weird for me, but the game's music is so good that it doesn't really matter anyway, you'll want to listen to the game's music.Overall, Shank is a very enjoyable side scroller with some platforming elements and a great story. If you don't mind a bit of blood (or a lot of blood, flying everywhere!) then I would consider this a must-have for fans of the beat-em-up genre. Shank plays like an old-style fighting arcade game, but with better graphics and infinitely better controls. If you're not sure if it's something you'd like, then why not grab the free demo and check it out? What I mean by this is that sometimes you'll fight one boss after the other, and because most of them are pretty easy, it kinda throws you off a bit, and you can get bored sometimes. And then sometimes you'll have to complete another 5 levels to get to the next boss, so it does feel a bit weird to me personally.Otherwise, overall, this is an exceptional indie game. One that will take you a bit of time to complete on Normal, and then a couple of hours to finish on Hard. 												When I started playing Shank I'd been already familiar with Klei Entertainment - their game, Mark of The Ninja, is one of my favourites and it is among those where I have 100% achievement completion. Of course, MoTN only came out 2 years later, therefore, I expected Shank would have its shortcomings.Now, Shank is a fast-paced, action-packed side-scroller that reminds us of the good-old beat 'em up games from the arcade era. We proceed from one screen to the other while getting rid of dozens of enemies and eventually coming to a boss battle. At our disposal we have melee weapons (chainsaw!) and some firearms. While nothing fancy, making combos with all of our available items is pretty cool in the heat of battle especially when enemies are pouring in from every which way!The game has cutscenes between the levels and a great accompanying soundtrack. While short (can be completed in a couple of hours), for hardcore gamers the hard mode is available offering an extra challenge by completely removing the checkpoints.There are 2 things that make Shank stand out. First, we immediately notice that the game has a comic book art style - this was later used to make MoTN happen and Shank also has a sequel with similar graphics style. Now, the 2nd and perhaps most interesting is the excessive gore / violence the game uses. I found it a bit too much at times - I admit this is the game's style but even the cutscenes have some pretty gory scenes for no apparent reason. I understand the game later on underwent an upgrade and as a result of that some of the more violent scenes were removed / edited including some nudity.Don't go looking for a story here as you do not really have one. This is Shank's tale of revenge against his previous employer but it really is just a basis for killing a whole bunch of enemies (they never really elaborate on the story). This is not necessarily a problem as you are here for the chainsaw! :)To summarise: Shank is a decent beat 'em up from Klei Entertainment which offers a couple of hours of entertainment if you do not really have any other game at your disposal. I look forward to completing its sequel! This is an easy pick-up - especially when discounted - just remember to use a controller!

												Klei is far and away my favorite developer just for the majesty that is Invisible Inc, but they have a plenty impressive catalog outside of that. Shank goes way back to their early days as their second title, and while it carries their distinct style it definitely feels like a sophomore effort. I love a good beat-em-up and Shank is packed to the brim with blood and combos, but it makes a few of the common mistakes that games of the genre often do.Have you seen Desperado? Good, you know the plot to Shank. Dead lady, three henchmen, one big bad. Your headlining character comes armed with knives, pistols, grenades, and a chainsaw to work his way through streets and rooftops full of thugs. There's a bit of climbing and swinging between fights but the bulk of your time is going to be spent comboing mooks to death and chugging 40s to get your health back.Keeping enemies corralled while you hack them to bits is key here, because Shank is a full 2D beat-em-up with no Z-axis movement. Your foes are a diverse bunch, with spry stick fighters, machete-wielding psychos, gun-totting troopers, lumbering brawlers straight out of Fist of the North Star, and more. The further you get in the more the groups are mixed, causing plenty of chaos and headaches when you have to manage melee, ranged, and explosive threats.Early on the slick combo system provides an easy hook for the game. Everything you do combos beautifully, no matter how you mash your light, heavy, and gun attacks. If you can turn that button-mashing into strategy you should be able to hang with the game pretty well, but by the time you get on the third minion's trail the challenge starts to get a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tty. There's more than one sequence with random explosives raining down on you, and a major late-game street brawl has four waves of foes capped with a minigunner who can easily stunlock you to death.You have plenty of tools besides just your three attacks, including two kinds of grapples and some very useful grenades. While mixing things up can help you get out of unfavorable brawls, it won't help you much against the bosses. Each big bad has a gimmick that must be exploited to beat them, unless you want to whittle their health down a sliver at a time. It's not always obvious what you should do but dying once will pop up a tip straight-up explaining the gimmick, which is a heavy-handed but effective way to address the difficulty.There's a lot of combat in this game over the two to three hours it'll take to beat, so minor aggravations can easily weigh Shank down. Even with all the enemy types it gets repetitive after awhile, playing out across sprawling, linear levels with no secrets or items to find. If you're just here to kill people, though, you'll get plenty of that in lavish comic book style. The game's cutscenes are a highlight, rendered like everything else in Klei's signature look, though the voice acting lacks the impact to really sell the scenes. Overall Shank is a bloody good time that drags in a few places but gives you more than enough action to make up for it.

												A number of Steam reviews, which I can only hope/presume have been written by exceedingly YOUNG people, seem to refer to the similarities between this game and a very recent movie series going by the name of "Machete".  These kids clearly need to track down some OLDER films - not to mention read some comics (y'know, those things they used to make with PAPER) - and generally catch up on their "grindhouse" and "exploitation" history a little.     First of all, before Robert Rodriguez got involved with Machete, there was Grindhouse, in which there was a fake PREVIEW for Machete.  Before that, he directed a little film (which bears an equal amount of similarity to this game) called Desperado.  THAT was a sequel-of-sorts to his very modest FIRST film, called El Mariachi.  We could then go on to mention that some guy named Quentin Tarantino started making (by-and-largely BETTER) films around the same time of somewhat same-ish ilk, and if we REALLY wanted to get pedantic we could acknowledge that there have in fact been DECADES full of movies directed by guys with names like John Woo and Sam Peckinpah without whom, let's face it, NONE OF THIS would have existed.  Oh, and then there's comic writers and artists like Frank Miller, who not only co-directed the film adaptation of his Sin City comics (with a certain aforementioned Rodriguez character), but whose distinctive silhouetted-action art-style (which he's been doing for decades) is co-opted more than once in the course of...THIS VERY GAME!  Which we should probably start talking about, in all fairness (since this is supposed to be a review of it an' all).  SO ENOUGH WITH THE MACHETE REFERENCES ALREADY, OKAY?!  The SEVENTIES were FULL of movies which could just as readily be cited as influences to this game.  And action anti-heroes were rapidly firing twin pistols back in the EIGHTIES, boys and girls, in ASIAN movies no less!  Anyway, enough geriatric ranting, on with the review.    Shank is good.  REAL good.  And kinda hard.  Sometimes REAL hard.  But is it unique?  No.  Just as its INFLUENCES (see last paragraph, just in case you missed it) aren't exactly brand-new, neither is the gameplay.  But is there anything wrong with this, when the game is by-and-largely good old-fashioned 2D side-scrolling beat-'em-up FUN?!  OF COURSE THERE ISN'T!!  I mean, I don't play many of these games these days, but just 'cause an idea is OLD doesn't mean it's inherently "bad".  Sure, it adds some SEMI-modernisms, like oodles of bloodshed and endearingly cartoonish visuals, but it's basically the same-old, same-old, albiet done WELL.  And there ain't nuthin' wrong with that in MY book.  Apart from some slightly ♥♥♥♥♥♥/awkward platforming bits and a baffling inability to assign any of the buttons to the mouse if you choose to play with keyboard, there really isn't that much to complain about.     Well, okay, one thing.  I actually got the ♥♥♥♥♥ and threw in the towel on the chapter immediately preceding the final boss battle, because I honestly do lack the patience these days to keep fighting the same twenty-seven guys over and over and over again in order to yet yet again reach that one bit where I keep dying, and the game's sudden, stubborn lack of check-points was forcing me to do just that.  Like I mentioned above, I'm gettin' old, so "beating" the VAST MAJORITY of the game is good enough for me, in all honesty.  A quick peek at a video walkthrough confirms that I didn't miss much, anyway.  Like I said...nothing truly new and ground-breaking here, but very solid entertainment for anyone with the patience and skillz (dat's skillz wit' a Z, ya'll) to see it through.  Guess I should try the sequel some time, too...  Verdict: 8.5/10.

While the analouge stick is good for aiming the ranged weapon, it felt a bit too indirect/unresponsive for character control.Generally it's pretty evident that it's a console port, as e.g. the devs didn't even bother hiding the mouse cursor during gameplay.I bought Shank1+2 at 75% off, and at that price it's just ridiculously high value for money, but even at full price it's a recommended purchase for fans of the genre.75%

												Fighting games are usually for a certain majority of players that like to improve their skills instead of having mindless fun, which isn’t a bad thing. It’s just that a lot of people are not going to enjoy it as much as DOOM or F.E.A.R in the long run. This happened to me as well. However, Shank manages to be a part fighting game with platforming elements to give it enough variation for replayability to make the game memorable and last longer. There’s even enough charm in the game that makes the game gritty and laws of nature defyingly funny in looks which took me by surprise the first time I played it. The gameplay and art style is what the developers put thought into and not the story, so If your (dumbfoundingly) thinking this game is for the deep and meaningful, then look somewhere else. gameplay The mechanics of the game is more of a simplified, yet well-made fighting mechanic that manages to be easy to learn but hard to master. You have your only light weapon the shives, your heavy weapons, your ranged weapons and your limited throwable. You can combine these attacks to deck out massive damage on your enemies with time. The first time you play this you will die, A lot. But with time you will get better and that just brings up the next mechanic. grabbing, you will love the grab move in the game because of the many things you can do to the thugs when you get your hands on them. Each weapon and move has a different variation on what you can do to the them and the others around you, especially throwing them against other enemies. The light attack with grab must be my favorite and my god is it brutal, anyone unfortunate enough to be in this situation will turn into a human ragdoll. Then we've got platforming, what do I have to say, meh. It’s not bad it’s just easier than it looks. They're so contextual and smooth to go through that it makes a super meat boy stage as hard as a boss fight for the protagonist. But their short and a nice change in the game that somehow fits the setting well with all the impossible leaps of faith and the ability to ♥♥♥♥ing climb walls with a pair of shives, how awesome is that. Artificial intelligence Basic enemies in the game are varied little in their shape, but what they make up for is in specialty. Any weapon that their holding will be used at the best of their abilities that fits the character’s movements. The light guys will usually use one handed weapons and numbers, the massive guys will mostly use two handed weapons and cover a large area, and the nimble girls will use light weapons and their movement. Even what weapon their using can dictate their health depending if they are ranged or melee. The variation is so large that even the enemies without weapons act differently, depending on their shape, which is quite impressive. There are only two kinds of boss fights in the game, one that acts like more of a puzzle to defeat, and the ones that require you to remember everything you did when you encountered specific enemies. The latter is the hardest because the only way to deck damage is to attack normally, because the puzzle enemies take as much damage in their weak points, as a light, ranged guy. This is more of a mixed thing because some of them I liked and some of them I just didn’t like. Atmosphere The art style in the game looks like a cartoon network version of “machete”. It’s well animated and entirely hand drawn. It doesn’t have hand drawn frames like “Skullgirls” but it looks good enough to be eye candy. The story fits the art style well with visceral violence mixed with bright colours to fit the theme. The story isn’t a timeless classic of our age, but is still good enough for the theme. The game story is about a guy “ironically” called shank and the story is unfolded to us about why he is taking vengeance against a group of organised criminals. It may sound serious but when you get to the point that you fight guys bigger than a house, why bother. The cut scenes look good, but the dialogue is purposely asinine at best. The story is mostly told through the cut scenes with the character interactions being forgettable, but the way it’s given to us is its strength making character building and storytelling good. I would be lying if I said that I didn’t like the protagonist and some of the characters. It’s dark, it’s scary, and that’s what it just wants to tell us. Negatives Now when you begin the game, one of the first things it shows to you is “recommended with controller”. Now you can play the game with the keyboard, it’s just that its layout is awful. The key binding scheme could have been laid out better, it just that the first time I played I assumed it was made without testing. It’s not a bad thing because you can bind the keys in ways to fit your style and you can play the game. An even bigger complaint is balancing. There’s so many weapons and enemies given to you that balancing can be a hard thing. Some weapons are overpowered, whereas there are weapons that do sod all damage, a good example is the ranged weapons. The shotgun can pierce through enemies and the charge attack with it can literally mostly clear out a room of hostiles, where the submachine gun does less damage than the pistols and it's only good trait is it’s grab attack variant that does the more damage than the shotgun. Certain enemies can be a pain, especially the dogs that tackle you and bite you to death. This wouldn’t be so bad if there wasn’t one attack you could do when you grab them and is just throw them, which does♥♥♥♥♥♥poor damage. Conclusion “Shank” has been recently overshadowed by its more smart and agile sister “mark of the ninja” which is probably a shame because it’s quite a good game. It manages to be a good 2D platforming fighting game for anyone who likes “F.E.A.R” or “DOOM” or generally feeling like a badass. If you want something to last and for something to show to your kids when you get older, buy this. You’ll like it, your kids will like it and you’ll probably bore your husband/wife to death when you talk about it.

												Shank is a 2D side scrolling action game from Klei Studios. This is the first in a series of two games and while the second game is a far more refined experience, the original is still fun in it's own way, even if it is a pretty simple game. I have to confess I played Shank 2 before the original so I am slightly more negatively biased towards the game as the first is missing a lot of improvements added in the sequel. This doesn't mean the game isn't fun, it just means it's relatively simple and superficial when it comes to mechanics. In Shank 2 you were almost required to have the proper load out to complete certain levels. In the first game, you have the option to switch weapons on the fly, but you probably won't need to as the two starting weapons (chainsaw and double pistols) can get you through the entire game pretty easily (hard mode included). Additionally there are only three enemy types (medium, large, dog) with a few variants. Once you know how to take down one variant, you can take down all of them with relative ease.I don't mean to say that Shank is a bad game, just one that needed to be fleshed out a little more. In terms of content it's a very short game and I was able to get all the achievements under 10 hours. There is a co-op campaign but it's local only which is very unfortunate because I found it to be pretty fun to double up with a friend and run through some missions. I actually prefer Shank's co-op to Shank 2's co-op (which is a really difficult survival mode). Shank's co-op (although local only) actually fleshes out the story a little more. There is an achievement for completing local co-op so make sure you've got a buddy and an extra controller if you plan on getting all the achievements.Overall Shank is a great looking 2D beat 'em up/shoot 'em up with a great soundtrack and fun bosses. The game may be relatively easy and simple and could use a little more content but it's still a blast to play.6.5/10

												By the time of this late review, you've probably have already made your mind about this nearly 3 year old game. I'm simply reviewing to state my interpretation. Shank is a revenge tale played in a 2D platforming brawler. Gameplay is somewhat comparble to the Devil May Cry series, with a standard attack, a secondary weapon attack and guns that can be switched on the fly, grapple and pounce moves, and a grenade to cause heavy damage. The combat is pretty simplistic, and often spammy, as mashing the standard attacks is sometimes the best way to deal with single enemies and small groups. That isn't to say there isn't some complexity with the fact that some enemies can shoot from afar, block or dodge your attacks, or perform unblockable power attacks. The majority of the combat boils down to managing gun shooters and grenade throwers while a handful of standard grunts and a "big guy" or two that require you to dodge or block their attacks. Platform segments are simple and are nearly automatic, but   can become a little annoying when you miss a grab point or are hit by a projectile mid-jump.The game's simplicity is both it's main pro and con - it's a simple, very short story with easy to grasp controls and enjoyable "mindless bloodshed". It also means the game becomes fairly predictable and leaves most the game easily beat by "spamming main attack" or "spamming pistols" until you win (this will not always work though, and it pays to mix it up on tougher enemies and large groups). I beat it in less than 3 hours, which is crazy short, but I'm also perfectly fine with that because any longer probably would have outstayed it's welcome for me. (another backlogged title defeated!).You won't find the new revolution in brawlers here, but you have a solid action title that's enjoyably mindless.

												In this genre of games, I think the masterpiece still stands as Final Fight. So I will mostly compare this with Final Fight.- The art greatly surpasses Final Fight, but it's not a direct result of 20 odd years that passed between these two games. Shank tries to establish its own style that has been a good mix of Metal Slug, Western and Tarantino movies and executes it near flawlessly. The game's greatest merit is its art to be honest.- Lack of ridiculous♥♥♥♥♥♥to do or secret locations. There aren't any of them unlike Final Fight where you beat a car for no good reason but still a good amount of fun and something to achieve and try to set a record on. Compared to Guacamalee, lack of secret locations also can be more noteworthy.- Comparing stories, Shank and Final Fight both follow a cliche story about a woman but Shank does it a lot better and the story has a good amount of Robert Rodriguez vibe, which I found incredibly done. Also the characters are fleshed out a lot more, unlike Final Fight's bosses.- When it comes to gameplay, Final Fight was much more superior. All of your combos made sense and were devoid of button mashing. Also Final Fight tried to keep combos and attack moves a lot simpler but timing of them and the strategy used to defeat a number of enemies in an area mattered much more than button mashing.- Final Fight allowed you to trap your enemies to a corner of the screen and beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them, which made the game a lot easier than it could have been if you couldn't exploit this. Shank carries this trope to some extent, you will mostly be able to corner your enemies and beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them except for bosses and some enemy types.- Some fights consists of throwing multiple waves of heavy enemies at you without having a chance to rest or save and it's pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Yes, the game scenario makes sense for you to fight them, but having a 8-10 minutes of constant fighting and starting all over when beaten just feels unfair to me.- Responsiveness of the controls are sometimes ♥♥♥♥ed, which was purely perfect for Final Fight. I often wondered why my fighter insisted on shooting at the opposite direction or failed to grab one item in multiple tries. When it comes to dodging, controls ♥♥♥♥ up more and you find yourself standing in the middle of 5 large enemies.- I won't be able to compare this with Final Fight due to era's technical limitations but compared to Guacamalee the amount of gore in the game is just lovely and it is very satisfying to violently strangle someone with chains or how you behead bosses.All in all, if you're interested in the genre or want something interesting, Shank can be a good choice when on sale and fortunately it goes on sale very frequently.

												Take everything I say about Shank with a big ol’ spoonful of salt; I don’t like platformers, I generally don’t like 2D side scrolling, and I hate brawlers and fighting games. So what is Shank? It is a 2D side scrolling brawler with comic book aesthetics and short elements of reactionary platforming.Needless to say I started off the first level with a sour taste in my mouth and my judgments pre-rendered. After all of that, I’m not going to make a 180 and say Shank is great, but I got WAY more enjoyment out of it than I ever expected. The fighting felt to me like a run-and-gun adaptation of the combat found in Mark of the Ninja (a game I actually am quite fond of). While the platforming certainly picked at my nerves, the sections were short enough that I was able to push through them and keep playing. Helping matters was that Shank is an absolutely gorgeous game from an aesthetic standpoint. The animations are clear and well fleshed out, the cut-scenes are very rich and capture that comic book vibe, and the colors - while a bit muted for my tastes - are varied from level to level.In the end, Shank is still a brawler. I don’t like memorizing combos and I don’t like how any fighting games handle. But I think in the end, that just says a lot for the quality that this game brings to the table. I’m not about to hand out my game of the year award, but Shank is pretty alright.

												This game reallhy isn't good gameplay-wise. The graphic style is nice. The vague story is a bad ripoff of Tarantino type revenge films. A mixed blessing is that it only takes 3 hours to beat. If it wasn't one of the cheapest games i've played since I had a NES, it probably only would have taken an hour and a half. The shortness of the game meant that I dealt with the frustration because I knew the end was in sight. If it was a 5-6 hour game, I probably would have quit after the first hour.The combat system is just plain boring and too random. It feels like luck is almost as important as skill; sometimes regular hitting combos turn into grapples when you don't want them to, which gives other enemies an open shot at you. Different weapon combinations don't really have much effect other than a couple just being generally worse than others. Pretty much all difficulty comes from the game just throwing tons of enemies at you that throw grenades and shoot assault rifles rather than actually making the enemies smarter or requiring more skill.Honestly, it feels like they prioritized the look and style and added the actual combat as an afterthought with no actual idea behind it other than it should look cool. Kung-fu on the NES has much better combat IMHO because it's 100% skill-based. There aren't any unavoidable deaths, your character reacts predictably and it's never cheap.Certain levels have missles come at you from offscreen and pieces of ceiling fall on you, much too fast to be able to react to, which adds nothing but frustration and random deaths.Pretty much all of the boss fights are glorified quicktime events. They all involve dodging and getting in the occasional hit that does next to no damage until the flashing "grapple now!" QTE graphic pops up, at which point your character does a specific attack animation. Each boss requires going through 4 of these QTE's to win. The devs got lazy, because even if you don't have a chainsaw or pistols equipped, your character wil still always use them for the QTE attacks.To top it all off, the developers made the huge mistake of adding a bunch of terrible platforming, with a few notable areas where trial-and-error is the only option. The missles from offscreen appear in one stretch that is super frustrating, and at one point you actually have to shoot your guns at an offscreen enemy to prevent him from killing you mid-jump.Anyways, I LOVED Mark of the Ninja, with a similar visual style by the same devs, because at it's core it's a great stealth game, but at Shank's core is a random button-masher of a fighter mixed with a horrible platformer.

What's it about?Shank is a side-scrolling brawler by Klei Entertainment, who also brought you such titles as Don't Starve and Mark of the Ninja. Playing as the titular protagonist, you make your way through several levels, slaughtering dozens of thugs and hired goons along the way on a one-man quest for revenge.How does it play?The undeniable strength of Shank is its combat. Within the first few minutes of the game, you'll be stringing together devastating combos utilising the weapons at your disposal. You have a light attack, a heavy attack and a firearm attack, and your heavy weapon and firearm can be swapped on the fly with weapons you pick up throughout the game. The fighting has a wonderful feeling of weight and impact to it, and hacking down the beautifully animated enemies is an absolute delight. The bosses are unusual and enjoyable to fight, though most can be beaten in more or less the same way. There is some rudimentary platforming involved in traversing the levels, which doesn't get in the way of the action too much.Because the game was designed for console, it is highly recommended that you use a controller to play it. Trying to play with the keyboard will turn out to be an altogether fiddly and unenjoyable experience, since the buttons you need will be all over the place. Shank uses almost every button and directional input on the controller, and that amounts to 16 keys on the keyboard. Another bugbear is that levels often involve hazards and enemy placements that can lead to unfair deaths and frustration; the church level in particular, with its falling missiles, can be a nightmare to get through. There is also an odd glitch with the chainsaw's jumping attack in which you and your target can become stuck if you try to jump before the attack animation is finished, forcing you to reload the last checkpoint. It is also not a very long game; I finished it in less than three hours, so take that into consideration before purchasing.How does it look?In a word, gorgeous. Keli have a knack for nailing their art styles, and Shank is no exception. The character sprites are beautifully designed and animated, and serve to make the already great combat look and feel even better. The environments are equally gorgeous, though there are points at which elements in the foreground appear onscreen and obscure parts of the stage. This often happens in areas with enemies, which can prove annoying when you are fighting or being attacked in a place you can't see. Despite this little problem, the graphics are delightful to look at, and the resolution options mean you shouldn't have a problem getting it to run on your system.How does it sound?Perhaps less impressive out of all of this is the sound design. The music mostly consists of loops of Mexican standoff-style tunes that fit the game very well, but can get a little repetitive after a while. The enemy shouts and grunts also get very samey (and for some reason, Shank's death rattle sounds almost identical to the Heavy from TF2). The various slashing and shooting sounds are well done, and the chainsaw in particular sounds like the industrial death machine it should. The voice acting in the cutscenes could have been better, but then again, the story is not what's important here.Long story shortShank is a brutal, bloody and highly entertaining beat-'em-up from a highly talented indie studio. The combat is some of the best I've experienced in a 2D game, and the art style is both beautiful to look at and serves to add to the combat experience. A few problems here and there, but Shank is a game that is definitely worth your time and money.Good PointsOutstanding combat systemGorgeous visualsInteresting environments and bossesBad PointsThe occasional game-breaking glitchSound design could have been betterSome questionable decisions in level and art designMay be too short for someRedWolf Rating: 6/10 - Good

												Another beautifully presented game about stabbing people from Klei Entertainment.Unfortunately, the game heavily falls victim to default optimal strategy, or the "Hadouken Effect," or whatever you want to call it. There are some beautiful and fantastic combos you can pull off if you're willing to experiment and become actually good at the game, but there is one move that will carry you through the entire game with almost zero effort that is quite easy to discover within the first ten minutes of play. Fast-forward through two hours of spamming this move over and over and you have the casual experience of Shank. If you have a friend willing to join you in your jump-slashing spam spree, you can get another two hours out of the local co-op campaign, which was actually quite surprisingly long (about as long as single-player) and to put that much effort into a co-op campaign and make it local-only is somewhat baffling to me.Also baffling is how the hard mode was handled. There are no checkpoints. Even the people who are really into this game admit that the hard mode is quite tedious and unfun. I'm all for arcade difficulty, and I would have expected a limited-lives system to come into play on hard mode, but you have literally one health bar to complete an entire stage. Ten minutes of gameplay in, and an enemy with a minigun can blow you to pieces with a stunlock-instadeath combo before you even know what happened. Hope you're good with the combat, otherwise you're going to repeat ten minutes of spamming again. This isn't even a pure beat-em-up, either. There are platforming sections, and the non-intuitive "hold right or left to advance, no matter what direction you're actually going" controls can easily send you plummetting to your inevitable instant death.This is a hard game to recommend, but after watching a walkthrough done by someone familiar with the game's combat engine, I think it has a lot of potential for the diehard beat-em-up fans. If you liked other Klei games, particularly Shank 2, try out the demo and see what you think. Unless you're willing to keep replaying it, however, I'd wait for a sale if I were you.

												Slick, varied and downright fun combat is really all this game is about. Sure, it has an attractive art style and an enjoyable (if somewhat cliché) soundtrack but its core is the 2D beat-em-up gameplay. Be sure you have a controller you can play with as I can't imagine playing this with the keyboard (I used a PS2 controller).For me, the highlight of Shank is its boss fights. Each one has a unique weakness that you can take advantage of. However, if you want more of a challenge or can't figure out the weakness, you have the option to whittle them down with normal attacks. While there isn't a huge variety in the grunts that you'll fight, I never grew tired of them because you steadily unlock new weapons that reinvigorate things and quite simply, the game isn't long enough to start getting bored. It also helps that you have 6 different attacks, a dodge/block button and jumping at your disposal as you combo your way to victory. There are some platforming bits that got tiring but fortunately the developers were smart enough to keep those sections short.The story is a very simple tale of revenge that is entirely forgettable but serves its purpose to drive the action forward. The voice acting is equally adequate without being distractingly bad nor anything noteworthy.Given Shank's short length it's hard to recommend at full price. But on sale or packaged in something like a Humble Bundle it will surely entertain you for an afternoon or two.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												As the game loads each time, you are instantly presented with a warning that you should be using a controller to play the game. This is unacceptable, as I've purchased it for PC, and I expect it to be played as such. Despite this misplaced excuse of a warning, Shank can be played and enjoyed with the keyboard. The controls and combinations aren't too pitiful, and you will be able to execute most of them as soon as you get used to how the mechanics work. The artwork is well done, in a comic book style setting. The voice acting is okay for what it is, but you should not expect them to be excellent. Even though the game is violent, the overall atmosphere is quite mild and cartoony. The story isn't very original nor is it interesting, but it does fit fine with the overall presentation and game play style. Even though Shank attempts to go back to the glory days of early to mid 90s Beat 'em ups, it comes off as unpolished and sometimes inadequate in some forced platforming elements. There is very little variety between the levels and enemies, and once you get acquainted with the moves, Shank gets increasingly repetitive in all aspects, and you will be hoping for a quick finish to the game. After a very short while, it all looks the same, feels the same, and plays the same. The unlocks don't add much at all, and there is very little to be gained with the weapons the game makes available to the player on a permanent basis as you progress through the story. The boss battles can often drag and do not offer any true challenge or difference in game play in comparison to the rest of the enemies. There is very little charm in Shank, in comparison to games of the same genre from earlier generations. It's button mashing without any skill or strategy whatsoever. The music and setting are akin to stereotypical Southwestern United States, and this provides the player with slight immersion to the theme, albeit a basic one. The general concept would have been better suited for a short animated film instead of a shallow and slightly subpar game. Tedious fight mechanics coupled with poorly designed boss battles makes for a forgettable and passable gaming experience.Shank is okay.

												Shank is a pretty nice 2D side-scrolling brawler video game which could have been made for 80s or 90s coin-operated arcade machines. It was developed in comic book art graphic convention mixed with Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodriguez style as well as great sound effects and appropriately feisty soundtrack. This game features plenty of enemies to be brutally exterminated with heavy melee weapons like chainsaw, some firearms and grenades. Posted: November 15, 2015
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Shank is the first game in the Shank franchise by Klei Entertainment, the wonderful people behind Mark of the Ninja. Shank and its sister sequel Shank 2 were developed before Mark of the Ninja and does not focus on straight stealth like Mark of the Ninja did, but full on action with the same art style and same bloody actionThe story basically shows us a guy named Shank who was tasked in killing his wife but was followed by some other gang members of Cesar where they kill his wife and leave him left for dead, this storyline made me say that it is something roughly around Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill volumes (which I highly recommend watching!)The game is exteremly short, homing in at around 3 hours. But it does have its good and bad sides. Bad, because it is extremly short but good because it does get repetitive after a while. Shank 2 apparently suffers with the same length problems homing in at around 4 hours long (checked via howlongtobeat.com), thankfully Shank does offer a New Game+ mode as well as a multiplayer campaign... but sadly, I don't have any friends to try it out :(The graphics are beautiful and made me remember playing Mark of the Ninja (I played Mark of the Ninja before Shank) as well as Disney cartoons, only Disney's cartoons are less bloody than Shank is. The animations are also really good, from the sword play to the gun fightingThe controls are very annoying on PC and it shows that Shank was originally developed for Xbox and then horribly ported onto the PC, it is impossible to play it on a keyboard, so much so that I had to plug in my controller to play it properly, and if you do happen to have a controller, I highly recommend playing with it as soon as you start. No wonder the game highly recommends playing with a controller when you boot up the game, it wasn't joking...The music and sound effects, are okay but nothing memorableYou will die, a lot, thankfully there is a fair checkpoint system in the game. The voice acting was okay but nothing special, it does suffer like Mark of the Ninja's voice acting, some good, some bad...I had fun playing Shank, even though it did have its fair share of problems here and there, but on the whole, it was a really good action game. Hopefully, its sequel would have ironed out most of the problems Shank had... hopefully... RECOMMENDED :)

												Shank is similar to a side scrolling God Of War.  Lots of enemies and lots of blood, with some sexual themes here and there, so it is not for the kiddos. Here is a weapon break down.Duel Pistols: have a good firing rate and good distance, but do not do a lot of damage so the larger enemies and bosses will barely notice them.Shanks: Primary attack.  Don't do much damage but are fast.Chainsaw: Does a lot of damage but is slow.Shotgun:  Does a lot of damage but is slow and does not have good range.  Is very effective against large enemies.Machetes: Faster than the chainsaws, but does less damage.Uzi: Fast firing rate and good distance, but not so powerful.Chains: Slightly slower than the mahetes but do more damage.Katana: Fast with good range and does some decent damage.Grenades: Shank starts every level with three but can hold up to five.  A throwable explosive that can damage or even kill enemies at a distance.  Should be used wisely.The game can get challenging and sometimes can get boring.  It is reccomended that Shank is played in spurts.  On normal mode, when Shank is defeated, he respawns nearby with full health.  But in Hard mode, there are no checkpoints. which means that every death sends Shank back to the start of the level, and the enemies are tougher than before.The bosses are fun to fight and have a stragety on how they are to be defeated, but some bosses feel like more powerful copies of previous bosses.Overall, if you like a beat em up, are okay at the sight of blood, and know how to get tactical in battle, Shank is a good game, but should be bought on sale.

Shank and its sister sequel Shank 2 were developed before Mark of the Ninja and does not focus on straight stealth like Mark of the Ninja did, but full on action with the same art style and same bloody actionThe story basically shows us a guy named Shank who was tasked in killing his wife but was followed by some other gang members of Cesar where they kill his wife and leave him left for dead, this storyline made me say that it is something roughly around Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill volumes (which I highly recommend watching!)The game is exteremly short, homing in at around 3 hours. But it does have its good and bad sides. Bad, because it is extremly short but good because it does get repetitive after a while. Shank 2 apparently suffers with the same length problems homing in at around 4 hours long (checked via howlongtobeat.com), thankfully Shank does offer a New Game+ mode as well as a multiplayer campaign... but sadly, I don't have any friends to try it out :(The graphics are beautiful and made me remember playing Mark of the Ninja (I played Mark of the Ninja before Shank) as well as Disney cartoons, only Disney's cartoons are less bloody than Shank is. The animations are also really good, from the sword play to the gun fightingThe controls are very annoying on PC and it shows that Shank was originally developed for Xbox and then horribly ported onto the PC, it is impossible to play it on a keyboard, so much so that I had to plug in my controller to play it properly, and if you do happen to have a controller, I highly recommend playing with it as soon as you start. No wonder the game highly recommends playing with a controller when you boot up the game, it wasn't joking...The music and sound effects, are okay but nothing memorableYou will die, a lot, thankfully there is a fair checkpoint system in the game. The voice acting was okay but nothing special, it does suffer like Mark of the Ninja's voice acting, some good, some bad...I had fun playing Shank, even though it did have its fair share of problems here and there, but on the whole, it was a really good action game. Hopefully, its sequel would have ironed out most of the problems Shank had... hopefully... RECOMMENDED :)

Pros: Satisfying hack'n'slash melee combo action Lovely comic style 2D animation Rodriguez/Tarantino style vengeance exploitation theme Short and sweetCons: Controls take a little getting used to Seems really hard until you realise it's really easy Moving around is a bit awkward Doesn't really inspire replays Perhaps a little too short and sweet?With its Mexican sets and pulp fiction vibe, Shank really digs into the Robert Rodriguez inspiration bucket, paying homage to films like Machete and El Mariachi. The thin story line is a vengeance tale where Shank fights wave after wave of nasty guys to get at the associates who had left him for dead. Really, I'd never ask for more from a hack'n'slash and I think it's quite a good fit for the game-play style. The artwork itself is really nice - they employ a clean line cartoon/comic style that looks a little bit like Bruce Timm or Genndy Tartakovsky coloured by Kyle Baker. (!!!)The game-play itself is side-scrolling melee action. Stacks of bad dudes come at you and you grind your way through them to get to the bosses. It has a bit of a Mega Drive (Genesis) vibe with the three attack buttons for light, heavy and gun items. You're encouraged to be creative with combos and to explore using direction as well to get different effects. At first I found it a little confusing to play. With a bit of time, though, I was able to chain-up purposeful combos to destroy the hoards in a very satisfying way. It's actually quite fun. There is a difficulty setting and on normal I found the enemies to be difficult enough, up until I had beaten a few bosses. Beating the bosses requires you to master a couple of moves - block which makes you virtually impervious, dodge with the same effect, and grapple which again makes you virtually impervious and which the enemies usually won't break out of. Knowing these few moves, suddenly the difficulty of the game bottoms out and the rest of the game, bosses and all, becomes a cake-walk. At this point you have to ask yourself if you wanted to be challenged or if you just wanted to destroy waves of enemies. If it's the second, then you're in luck - as long as you don't mind finishing in 4 to 6 hours. It is a very short game. Without permadeath, the game turns into one of those where you see how quickly you can finish the stages with the least amount of deaths and to be honest, that never motivated me to replay a game.Nevertheless, the makers do try to make Shank replayable. There is a hard mode which has less checkpoints and harder enemies which is largely uninspiring. There is also concept artwork and costumes for Shank, however it is never explicitly clear what you need to do to unlock this content. I think that moving around the scenery was a little flawed. Shank can parkour (in a limited fashion) through the scenery. There are a couple of sequences where you need to use a bit of platforming skills but Shank is a terrible platformer! All I wanted to do was kill bad guys but in a few limited sections I had to replay the awkward plaforming ten times over. I'd have rather just had extra bad guys to attack. Probably the only thing I was vocally upset about, though, was that despite clearly stating that the game is best played with a gamepad, the game never disables the mouse pointer which mocks you in the middle of the playfield until you stand up, walk over to the rig and swat the cursor out of the way. It's a small grievance, I know, but it's still a drag.For what it is though, I found it to be an enjoyable return to the side-scrolling action games I used to love.

												This game should've been a shoo-in for a recommendation. A classic side-scrolling beat 'em up with a graphic novel feel set in the Mexican underworld featuring machetes, chainsaws and epic wrestlers? What could go wrong?Firstly, the good. The game is pretty gorgeous, nicely stylised backdrops and beautiful graphics generally. Over-the-top gory action is par for the course, with you cutting through legions of troops with guns, blades and grenades. Whilst the game warns that it plays better with a gamepad, it's still perfectly playable on a keyboard, with enough move combinations and enemies to keep the game interesting. There's even a passable storyline!Yet something went awry with the game testing. There are only two difficulty modes. The easier one is so straightforward that the game only lasts just over an hour. Although the learning curve is pretty well planned, there aren't many tricky sections, the boss fights feel like choreographed cutscenes, and you're more likely to die from learning where the pitfalls are or being hit by a random projectile. You'd think the hard mode would fix these issues, making the game more challenging, but whilst the bad guys have indeed been beefed up and the fights become much more tense as a result, more importantly each level has to be completed without checkpoints! Since some of the levels are over 10 minutes long (one even includes a mini-boss fight halfway through), there's just oodles of frustration waiting to be had here attempting the missions over and over, only to fall down a hole you didn't even know was there after 10 minutes of playing and have to restart.Overall a decent little game for the price, especially if you can pick it up on offer. The graphics are gorgeous, the gameplay entertaining, and there's even a little local co-op which I haven't yet tried. But the fact that this game only comes with game modes for children and masochists and nothing in between makes it difficult to give more than a borderline recommendation.
